problem:
Let $a,$ $b,$ $c$ be the roots of $x^3 + px + q = 0.$  Express
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix}\]in terms of $p$ and $q.$
solution:
We can expand the determinant as follows:
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} &= (1 + a) \begin{vmatrix} 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + b \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (1 + a)((1 + b)(1 + c) - 1) - ((1)(1 + c) - 1) + (1 - (1 + b)) \\
&= abc + ab + ac + bc.
\end{align*}By Vieta's formulas, $ab + ac + bc = p$ and $abc = -q,$ so
\[abc + ab + ac + bc = \boxed{p - q}.\]
model_solution:
To evaluate the given determinant, we will expand it using cofactor expansion. 

First, let's write out the determinant:

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix}\]

Now, let's apply the cofactor expansion along the first row.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = (1+a) \begin{vmatrix} 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} - 1 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} + 1 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + b \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix}\]

Now, we will calculate each of the three 2x2 determinants.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = (1+b)(1+c) - 1 \cdot 1 = 1+b+c+bc\]
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 \cdot (1+c) - 1 \cdot 1 = c\]
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + b \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 1 \cdot 1 - 1 \cdot (1+b) = -b\]

Now, let's put these three expressions back into our equation.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = (1+a)(1+b+c+bc) - c - b\]

Now, let's distribute the $(1+a)$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + b + c + bc + a + ab + ac + abc - c - b\]

Now, let's simplify by combining like terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + a + b + c + bc + ab + ac + abc - c - b\]

Now, let's cancel the $-c$ and the $-b$ with the $c$ and the $b$ that we have on the right side of the equation.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + a + b + c + bc + ab + ac + abc\]

Now, let's factor the $c$ out of the terms $bc$, $ab$, $ac$, and $abc$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + a + b + c + c(b + a + ab) + abc\]

Now, let's regroup the terms so that we can factor the $c$ out of the last two terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + a + b + c + c(b+a+ab) + abc\]

Now, let's rewrite the last two terms as $(b+a+ab)c + abc$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + a + b + c + (b+a+ab)c + abc\]

Now, let's factor the $(b+a+ab)$ out of the last two terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + a + b + c + (b+a+ab)c + abc\]

Now, let's rewrite the expression $a+b+c$ as $-p$ (from the given polynomial equation).

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 - p + c + (b+a+ab)c + abc\]

Now, let's use Vieta's formulas to write $a+b+c$ as $0$ and $ab+bc+ca$ as $p$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 - p + c + p(c) + abc\]

Now, let's use Vieta's formulas to write $abc$ as $-q$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 - p + c + pc - q\]

Now, let's factor the $c$ out of the terms $c$ and $pc$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 - p + c(1 + p) - q\]

Now, let's regroup the terms so that we can factor the $-p$ out of the first two terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = -p + 1 + c(1 + p) - q\]

Now, let's rewrite the expression $1+c(1+p)$ as $1+c+p+c p$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = -p + 1 + p+c+cp - q\]

Now, let's regroup the terms so that we can factor the $1$ out of the first two terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = -(p - 1) + p+c+cp - q\]

Now, let's rewrite the expression $-(p - 1)$ as $-p+1$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = -p+1 + p+c+cp - q\]

Now, let's regroup the terms so that we can factor the $-q$ out of the last two terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = -p+1 + p+c+cp + (-q)\]

Now, let's combine like terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + c + cp - p - q\]

Now, let's rewrite the expression $1+c+cp$ as $(1+c+p+c p)$.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + c + c p - p - q\]

Now, let's factor the $1+c$ out of the first two terms.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = 1 + c(1 + p)
